If Tom Yulsman is all for openness, would he be ready to help

- publicize the graph of the raw measured global temperatures in the last century, including the last 30 years of satellite data which all show very clearly that the behavior of global temperatures between 1910-1950 matches incredibly well the period 1970-2010, including the decline of global temperatures between 2002 and now?

http://www.woodfortrees.org...

- help publicize the fact that the summer Arctic ice extent, low in 2007 was last year 2/3 of the way back to normal, and that in 1922 there was a well documented Arctic ice meltdown, from which the ice recovered without problems?

http://www.ijis.iarc.uaf.edu...

These are measurements, not matters of opinion. If the public at large would have a chance to know them then any child would see that the climate with high CO2 levels has behaved exactly like the climate with high CO2 levels.

Instead people like Yulsman try to keep the measured climate data hidden, and as a smokescreen complain of being misunderstood.

"We’ve had more than 20 years of communication of climate science." What a nonsense... There have been 20 years of one sided statements instead of a dialogue - as exemplified by Al Gore who never takes questions - which continues even now. The global temperature graph, which is central to the whole subject, would NEVER make the front page of the science section of the NYT, or appear on any network TV news. Same with the polar ice, where the NYT is frozen in time to 2007.

There have been 20 years of hidden and manipulated data and of partial truths with consequences blown out proportion. Even this dialogue is kept out of the general public eye. It is not printed, even in excerpt form, by the NYT.

One side still has the microphone, and won't let anyone else get near it.

And now, when the public at large, even the NYT readers, don't swallow this any more, they start to complain about communication?

Start a real dialogue. Have Sunday morning TV debates between climate scientists and leading nonpolitical AGW dissenters, with real data on display. Have the NYT science section, or the Sunday magazine, have an equal space dialogue.

What are they afraid of, and why?

#28 Ivan Carter says:

"It is not that Raven is "risk tolerant." It is that Raven has absolutely no conception as to what the risks actually are"

Life is full of risk. A meteor strike, a pandemic, an alien invasion or a super volcano are all plausible risks that humanity could face over the next 100 years. I have seen no compelling evidence that the risk of catastrophe from climate change is any higher than the risk of any of those events.

The trouble with alarmists is not so much their risk aversion but their selective blindness. For example, every expert who understands the electrical generation system (i.e. the people who keep the system running today) knows that renewables are a joke and will never supply more than a small fraction of our electricity. A similar problem exists with plug in electric cars. Yet alarmists have no problem making huge bets on technology that we know does not work. This is nonsense and a waste of resources.

If you really believe that their the a tangible risk from climate change then we better focus on adaption because the world's CO2 emissions will not decrease over the next 50 years unless there is a unexpected breakthrough in technology.

Frankly, I am tired of the hypocritical moralizing from alarmists. If you want to panic about climate change then go reduce your own carbon footprint but leave the rest of us alone.

"I absolutely agree with Tenney

All scientists responsible for funding the spread of lies and misinformation to expedite action on becoming fossil-fuel carbon emissions free should be tried for crimes against humanity. They bear a great part of the responsibility for the coming economic crisis for most citizens on this planet."

I don't agree with Tenney at 43, who says the same of those who spread misinformation to delay action, believing it to be counterproductive; in some ways only furthering the problem, and only adding to a climate where witchhunts--whom the political opponents of Tenney are many times better at -- and rhetoric have far too much influence.

Misleading and often ideologically lead rhetoric will always have an undue effect when it is largely unchecked.

By Democrats and moderates largely dismissing the importance of fox, often taking for granted what everybody knows or should know, sometimes impugning the very voters they need to reach, losing credibility by ascribing ill willed or evil motives to those they disagree with, believe to be wrong (sometimes to each other) or who they think are lying, and being far too tolerant and even sometimes dismissive of the role of the media (thinking that the self reinforcing and often polarizing blogosphere somehow substitutes for it) along with the gradual breakdown of our necessary Fourth Estate media check upon rhetoric, power and misrepresentation into a gradually increasingly stenographic and false balanced reflection of it, we are losing effective checks upon rhetoric run amuck.

As a result, the most misinformed and often, most misleading and best spin artists among us (and often the most inflammatory and ignorant to boot) are becoming those who increasingly help shape the national debate.

The solution is to find that check. Since leopards don't tend to change their spots, and it is doubtful that Democrats will ever find the spinning capabilities of their political counterparts (rhetoric almost always wins out, hence why the right is being taken over by the far right wing) or see the need to start controlling the debate or know how to do it, the only real solution is to reinvigorate an actual, accountable, independent media.

We've got a long way to go, and are moving in the wrong direction. Dems don't even seem to get this, or they would be focusing in Congress right now at least on anti trust media issues and media conglomeration, and looking, at the least, at things likeSenator Ben Cardin's proposal, which is at least a start.

Here's a classic example, with both explanation and well supported example, of what actual bias is today being confused with, and what it really is.

Investigative, non kowtowing journalism needs to be brought back.

Andy. I am a relative newcomer to this blog, but was wondering if you were ever taught any classical logic, of the Aristotelian sort, perhaps at Brown? And if you were, did you ever come across the concept of "begging the question"? This is where you assume as an undisputed premise the very conclusion that is in dispute.
Scientists learn during their training how to "self correct". We often make mistakes in formal logic, but when we lay them out, our ear is tuned for logical error. So we catch ourselves. In part, we do so because we know that if we do not, someone else will do it for us.
In the four weeks that I have been reading your blog, I have counted 18 times where your headline has "begged the question." Just like this one today. The title "On the Causes of Climate Deadlock" begs the question.
The question at issue is whether or not legislation should be passed to prevent human CO2 release, in part because the such legislation it based on a dispute as to whether the feedbacks that control Earth's temperature are amplifying (meaning that a small warming will lead to further warming) or damping. Further questions in dispute are whether CO2 is a major (or even significant) contributor to natural regulation of global temperature, whether human activity will overwhelm natural temperature regulation (which historically hasbeen damping),and whether ground-based measurement that suggest that the Earth has slightly warmed over the past 150 years are unduly influenced by local phenomenon. These are all open question.
Your title "begs" all of these, as it leaps past the question at issue, and claims that the interesting question is why that legislation has not already been passed. You seem to think that "deadlock" is a bad thing that we need to "explain". Had you not begged the question, you would have posed a more neutral title ("Why has legislation based on the AGW hypothesis not passed Congress?") Or had you begged the question in the opposite direction, you might have asked: "Why is climate legislation still being considered?"
Are you incapable of catching this kind of thing in your own writing? Or are you doing this deliberately to provoke those among your readers who understand logic and apply it in our daily activities? Or perhaps, do you think that logic should not guide journalism as it relates to public policy?
Please do not take this as snark. I really want to know. As an educator in science, my task is to figure out where I need to begin, to get the student to learn. If you explicitly reject logic as a tool for guiding public policy, we need to start at a different place in your education than we must start if you just do not understand logic and how to apply it to argumentation.

Re (#30)
"Brian M. beat me to it. I quote Yulsman: 'such an attempt at intimidation by a government official is pretty disturbing.'

If he didn't say something similar regarding Hansen, he can go soak his head."

I don't agree with Hansen either. Couple of differences though:

First, somewhat minor; I don't think Hansen singled anyone out. (Maybe he did, I’m not sure, but it seems like it’s more general). He was speaking in generalities; he did not proscribe investigation and action on someone he disagreed with. And he was perhaps speaking in part as hyperbole.

Far more troublingly, he is also not a sitting Senator with the power to actually launch investigations. And he was likely speaking in part as hyperbole. (I think Yulsman later made this point as well.)

But there is yet another difference that is hard to quantify.

HANSEN’S VIEW ON THIS: Taking tens of millions of years of built up greenhouse gases and releasing them into the atmosphere in a geologically instantaneous period of time, given the signs we have seen, and his (scientifically well supported) interpretation of them, and the underlying physics, and continuing to do it, is being wildly reckless with our kids and their kids’ worlds, to the point of ridiculousness (or blindness?) almost.

Of course, not as many have as clear feel for the actual science involved as Hansen-- though millions of viewers of fox and blogs such as watts up and the rest, almost comically and sadly, believe that they do -- and Hansen may be ascribing far more scientific knowledge and better information on the part of those whom he castigates than reality really warrants.

INHOFE’S POINT: The basic idea that radically increasing the atmospheric levels of ghg to levels well above any the earth has seen in nearly a million years and very likely millions of years; when the greenhouse effect is known, basic science; when we have observed (for whatever it is worth) a warming trend -- if likely severely lagging, for reasons I have gone over in other comments; and which the great majority of the world's actual scientists who have studied this issue are greatly concerned about, is a hoax.

See the difference?

None of these differences make Hansen right (in my estimation) or very helpful when he suggests this. But he is not a senator; he is not opening up investigations for what in the greater scheme of things are routine science errors (if that) and prejudices (if that) in any other science context; and he is a well respected scientist who has been studying this issue -- and largely been accurate on it -- for over thirty years, who is looking at the blatant misinformation (and probably in his mind, abject foolishness) of the assertions and accusations being hurled about, and is, likely, frustrated.

A commenter above (Mike M) talks about the again private emails of some scientists showing their increasing frustration at all the misinformation and misrepresentations out there as an example of how we can't have a civil dialogue, but misses the point of the enormous misinformation and constant and often ridiculously misleading and unfair pilloring of scientists as individuals and as a whole -- and how this is also not helping us arrive at any informed thinking or decisions on this matter, but just the opposite:

Which may well be exactly what Inhofe wants, which is exactly why those who have convinced themselves that climate change is not a big deal now simply continue to attack the science, and thus perpetuate this same misperception of the underlying issue.

The relevance of this book (which is not nearly as political as its title suggests) comes to mind.

Replying briefly to Ivan Carter's (#28) response.

Ivan says "Read my comments on this blog: Nothing is alarmist regarding the problem; all emphasize it is a big problem and give the objective basis as to why. No prescriptions for redress are remotely anything like what this commenter has re characterized the idea of aggressively addressing climate change as."

I agree, which is why I've consistently favored your kind of approach. Read *my* comments. I tend to think AGW concerns are vastly overblown, but there are other and better reasons to move in the direction you describe. Besides, I could be wrong. It's a big error bar.

You have, however, proven the very point I was inartfully attempting to make. You and I don't disagree much on policy, and not even all that much on science. However, you feel moved to characterize my view as "ridiculous" and "far afield" -- perhaps beyond the pale of discourse entirely -- because I don't buy the entire enchilada and don't view the matter as a litmus test of faith, basic rationality, or moral standing.

What's needed here is a pragmatic accommodation of values under conditions of very imperfect information. What you demand is that I adopt your entire worldview -- a religious conversion, or, at the least, the Kuhnian paradigm shift to which I alluded.

What can I say, other than "QED"?
